citation.article-title: Pseudomonas antimicrobica, a new species strongly antagonistic to plant pathogenes.

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas antimicrobica sp. nov.

The cells were straight, non-spore-forming rods, 0.5 x 0.8-1.5 μm, Occurring singly, in groups, and occasionally in pairs, Gram-negative, aerobic, heterotrophic and motile with one to two polar flagella.
Two colony types were observed on nutrient agar.

Those of one variant (NCIB 9897) were circular, raised, creamy-white and opaque, rugose: and butyrous with raised, microundulate margins at 5 d, while the other (NCIB 9898) was moist, smooth, glistening and slightly viscid with· entire margins and occasionally an orange tinge.
Nutrient broth cultures at 4 d showed turbidity and thin to membranous pellicles which broke easily when disturbed.
A yellowish-orange, water-soluble, nonfluorescent pigment was produced in medium A and B of King et al. (1954), tyrosine medium, and various others.
An orange weakly diffusible pigment was produced in Czapek Dox, nutrient, and some other common laboratory agar media, but not in PDA.
Good growth occurred between 15° and 37°C, with a broad optimum around 30°C; there was no growth at 41°C.
Growth occurred in the presence of up to 4% sodium chloride, but weakened to a trace at 6%.
Levan type colonies were not produced; poly-β-hydroxybutyrate was not stored in the cells; no pectolytic activity or rotting of vegetable tissue was found.

Acid but not gas was produced from arabinose, dulcitol, fructose, galactose, glucose, glycerol, lactose, mannitol, meso-inositol, sorbitol, and xylose, but not from maltose, raffinose, salicin or sucrose.

Utilization tests showed that N-acetylglucosamine, D-alanine, L-arabinose, caprate, citrate, gluconate, glucose, glutamate, p-hydroxybenzoate, DL-hydroxybenzoate, meso-inositol, α-ketoglutarate, malonate, mannitol, Dmannose, phenylacetate, L-proline, propionate, and raffinose were used as sole carbon sources, but not adipate, D-iso-ascorbate, malate, or meso-tartrate.
Starch and ethanol were not assimilated.
In litmus milk the dye was slowly reduced and a whitish sediment formed without curd; the final pH was slightly alkaline.

Positive results were observed for nitrate reductase, lecithinase, lipolysis, 2-ketogluconate production, aesculin hydrolysis, Simmons citrate and Leifson's malonate, and negative results for indole and hydrogen sulphide production, oxidase, arginine dihydrolase, accumulation of poly-β-hydroxybutyrate, denitrification, and hydrolysis of gelatin and cellulose.
L-Asparagine, ammonium and nitrate were all used as sole nitrogen sources.
Vitamins and growth factors were not required.
A wide spectrum of antibiotic activity was present.
The two variants showed only minor differences, mainly in colony morphology and were considered to belong to one species.
